The test method is designed to detect compound‐induced disturbances in neurite outgrowth and cell viability in human dopaminergic neurons. In turn, it is related to adverse outcomes such as neurodegeneration (e.g. loss of dopaminergic neurons that characterizes Parkinson’s disease), impaired neuronal network function, and cognitive deficits including learning and memory impairment. Specifically, the assay is linked through AOPs to outcomes such as:

• Excitotoxicity and neurodegeneration (AOP 48)  
• NMDAR-related dysfunction and consequent learning/memory deficits (AOP 13)  
• Inhibition of mitochondrial complex I leading to parkinsonian motor deficits (AOP 3)  
• Additional links via thyroid hormone synthesis alteration that impact neuronal network function and cognitive performance (AOP 42, AOP 54, AOP 8, AOP 134)

These linkages support its use as a toxicological tool to predict adverse outcomes related to both developmental and adult neurotoxicity.  
(Sources: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf)

The differentiation protocol is based on a well‐defined timeline with specific medium changes and handling steps to convert proliferating LUHMES cells into post‑mitotic dopaminergic neurons. A simplified scheme is as follows (Sources: EFSA NAMs Case Study on Tebufenpyrad, Part 2 – Annex A, sections 3.6 and 4):

1. Pre‐differentiation (Day –1):  
 • Proliferating LUHMES cells are seeded in proliferation medium on plastic ware that has been pre‐coated with poly‑L‑ornithine (PLO) and fibronectin.  
 • The coating is done by incubating a solution of PLO (43 µg/ml) and fibronectin (1 µg/ml) overnight, followed by a wash and drying under sterile conditions.

2. Initiation of Differentiation (Day 0):  
 • The proliferation medium is completely replaced with differentiation medium.  
 • Differentiation medium contains tetracycline (1 µg/ml) to stop v‑myc expression, along with GDNF (2 ng/ml) and db‑cAMP (1 mM) to promote neuronal differentiation.  
 • This triggers the onset of neurite outgrowth and the initial development of the neuronal phenotype.

3. Pre‑treatment and Re-plating (Day 2):  
 • At this stage, cell numbers reach about 20–30 million per T75 flask.  
 • Cells are then trypsinized and re-plated into 96‑well plates at a density of 30,000 cells per well in 90 µl of differentiation medium that now uses galactose instead of glucose.  
 • The medium in these wells is deliberately formulated without cAMP and GDNF to prepare the system for compound exposure.  
 • Approximately 30 minutes to 2 hours after re‑plating, once cells (which appear round and not yet fully attached) are in place, compounds are added (10 µl each dilution).

The analytical approach relies on live-cell imaging of differentiated LUHMES neurons in 96‐well plates to capture two endpoints—neurite outgrowth and viability—in the same well and under identical conditions. On day 3 (approximately 24 hours after toxicant exposure), cells are live‐stained with two fluorescent dyes: Hoechst H‑33342 labels nuclei and calcein‑AM stains the cytoplasm of viable cells. The cells are not fixed or homogenized, meaning that all measurements are performed on intact, living cells.

Images are acquired using a high-content microscope (Cellomics Array Scan) with a 20× objective over approximately ten fields per well, ensuring that a representative number of cells (hundreds per well) are included in the analysis. In one imaging channel, the Hoechst signal is used to detect individual nuclei. Using a machine-learning–based algorithm, the nuclear outlines are identified and then expanded by a defined distance (3.2 µm) to generate a virtual cell soma area. In parallel, the calcein‑positive signal is recorded in another channel, where all calcein-positive structures are quantified. The neurite area is calculated by subtracting the soma region (defined by the expanded nuclear outlines) from the total calcein-positive area.

Viability is determined by evaluating the intensity of the calcein signal within the virtual cell soma areas, where only nuclei with a positive calcein signal, based on preset intensity thresholds, are counted as viable cells. This simultaneous measurement provides a parallel readout of both neurite outgrowth (as an indicator of neuronal connectivity) and cell viability in the same cells and wells.

_(Sources: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf)_

question: Provide information on machine settings, analytical standards, data processing and normalization procedures. For imaging endpoints: provide detailed algorithm. This information should also be covered in an SOP, preferably in DB-ALM format (see link in 6.6).
gtruth_answer: Quantification of neurite outgrowth An automated microplate reading microscope (Array-ScanII HCS Reader, Cellomics, PA) equipped with a Hamamatsu ORCA-ER camera (resolution 1024 x 1024; run at 2 x 2 binning) was used for image acquisition. Ten fields per well were imaged. Images were recorded in 2 channels using a 20x objective and excitation/emission wavelengths of 365 ± 50/535 ± 45 to detect H-33342 in channel 1 and 474 ± 40/535 ± 45 to detect calcein in channel 2. In both channels, a fixed exposure time and an intensity histogram-derived threshold were used for object identification. Neurite pixels were identified using the following image analysis algorithm: nuclei were identified as objects in channel 1 according to their size, area, shape, and intensity which were predefined on untreated cells using a machine-based learning algorithm, and manual selection of nuclei to be classified as intact. The nuclear outlines were expanded by 3.2 µm in each direction, to define a virtual cell soma area (VCSA) based on the following procedure: The average width of the cytoplasm ring (distance nucleus - cell membrane) of LUHMES cells was experimentally determined to be 2.3 µm. Size irregularities were not always due to growing neurites, as determined by combined F-actin/tubulin beta-III staining. To avoid scoring of false positive neurite areas, the exclusion ring (VCSA) was made bigger than the average cell size. Then, we used two control compounds (U0126 and bisindolylmaleimid I) to vary the expanded outlines from 0.6 to 4 µm. We found 3.2 µm to be optimal both to detect neurite growth over time and to identify reduced neurite growth with high sensitivity. All calcein-positive pixels of the field (beyond a given intensity threshold) were defined as viable cellular structures (VCSs). The threshold was dynamically determined for each field after flat field and background correction and intensity normalization to 512 gray values and was set to12% of the maximal brightness (channel 63 of 512). The VCS defines the sum of all somata and neurites without their assignment to individual cells. In an automatic calculation, the VCSAs, defined in the H- 33342 channel, were used as filter in the calcein channel and subtracted from the VCS. The remaining pixels (VCS - VCSA) in the calcein channel were defined as neurite area. Quantification of individual viable cells by imaging For a quantitative assessment of viable cells, the same images used to assess neurite area were analysed using another image analysis algorithm: nuclei were identified in channel 1 as objects according to their size, area, shape, and intensity. Nuclei of apoptotic cells with increased fluorescence were excluded. A VCSA was defined around each nucleus by expanding it by 0.3 µm into each direction. Calcein-AM staining, labelling live cells, was detected in channel 2. The algorithm quantified the calcein intensity in the VCSA areas. Cells having an average calcein signal intensity in the VCSAs below a predefined threshold were classified by the program as “not viable”. Valid nuclei with a positive calcein signal in their cognate VCSA were counted as viable cells. A positive calcein signal was based on measurements of the average intensity (normal cells: 1300 ± 115, threshold: < 50) and the total integrated intensity (normal cells: 186,000 ± 23,600, threshold < 1000) of cells.
gtruth_answer_quality_justification: The answer provides detailed information on the imaging equipment, settings, and algorithms used for neurite outgrowth quantification and viable cell assessment. Additionally, there is no mention of an SOP or reference to the DB-ALM format as requested in the question.
llm_answer:
The assay uses an automated high‐content imaging system with clearly defined machine settings, data processing procedures, and an imaging endpoint algorithm that is also documented in the DB‑ALM SOP (see section 6.6).

Machine settings and analytical standards:
• The imaging is performed using a Cellomics Array Scan VTI HCS Reader equipped with a Hamamatsu ORCA‑ER camera running at a resolution of 1024 × 1024 pixels and 2 × 2 binning. A 20× objective is used.
• Two channels are set up: channel 1 detects Hoechst H‑33342 (excitation 365 ± 50 nm; emission 535 ± 45 nm) for nuclei identification, and channel 2 detects calcein-AM (excitation around 474 ± 40 nm; emission 535 ± 45 nm) for marking viable cells.
• Exposure times are set manually, and an intensity histogram‑derived threshold is applied for object identification. For the calcein channel, after flat‐field and background correction an intensity normalization to 512 gray values is performed and a dynamic threshold is set at 12% of the maximal brightness.
• Analytical standards include running well‐established positive (e.g. narciclasine, HA‑1077, blebbistatine) and negative (0.1% DMSO) controls. These standards ensure that the imaging and readout parameters (i.e. neurite area and cell count) fall within defined acceptance ranges.

Data processing and normalization procedures:
• Raw images are acquired with the Array Scan hardware and then processed using the Array Scan software. The software identifies objects and quantifies endpoints (neurite area and cell number).
• Data are copied and collated in Excel files. Further analysis and curve fitting (using a four‑parameter log function via least squares regression) are carried out in GraphPad Prism and with additional tools such as BMCeasy.
• For normalization, readouts (neurite area, cell counts, and viability levels) are usually expressed relative to solvent (0.1% DMSO) controls. Any concentration‐response curves are generated on these normalized data.

Detailed imaging endpoint algorithm:
1. Nuclei Identification (Channel 1):
 • Objects (nuclei) are identified based on predefined criteria (size, area, shape, intensity) that have been optimized on untreated controls using a machine‑learning algorithm.
2. Definition of Virtual Cell Soma Area (VCSA):
 • For neurite quantification, each identified nucleus is expanded by 3.2 µm in all directions. This “exclusion ring” (VCSA) is chosen after optimization with control compounds to avoid scoring false positive neurite pixels.
3. Identification of Viable Cellular Structures (VCS) using Calcein Signal (Channel 2):
 • All calcein-positive pixels (above the dynamically determined intensity threshold) are summed to generate the VCS. These pixels represent both cell bodies and neurites.
4. Neurite Area Calculation:
 • The VCSA (predominantly representing the cell body) is subtracted from the VCS. The remaining pixels are attributed to neurites, and their summed area is quantified as the neurite endpoint.
5. Quantification of Viable Cells:
 • An additional algorithm quantifies viability by again detecting nuclei (with slight expansion by 0.3 µm to form a VCSA specific for viability measurement) and then assessing the average calcein signal intensity in these areas. Cells with integrated intensities below predefined thresholds (average intensity <50 and total intensity <1000, based on normal cell values) are classified as non‐viable.
 
All of the above procedures are documented in the DB‑ALM SOP (protocol no. 200) as described in section 6.6 of the provided document (link: https://ecvam-dbalm.jrc.ec.europa.eu/methods-and-protocols/protocol/ukn4-assay-to-test-compound-derived-impairment-in-neurite-outgrowth-in-differentiating-human-dopaminergic-neurons-protocol-no.-200/key/p_1602).

_(Source: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf)_

1. Narciclasine  
 • Why MCC: Narciclasine activates the Rho pathway, leading to inhibition of neurite outgrowth without significantly affecting cell viability.  
 • Expected Data: A reduction in neurite area (down to ≤75% of the DMSO control) while cell viability remains ≥90% compared to control.  
 • Day‐to‐day Use: Narciclasine is used as the primary positive control for test performance and for setting acceptance criteria.  
  (Source: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf, sections 5.5 and 5.9)

2. HA‑1077  
 • Why MCC: HA‑1077 is a Rho-associated kinase (ROCK) inhibitor that counteracts the Rho pathway’s inhibitory effect on neurite outgrowth.  
 • Expected Data: An increase (or preservation) in neurite outgrowth compared to controls, indicative of enhanced neurite area with maintained viability.  
 • Pathway Effect: Inhibition of ROCK (i.e. blocking a pathway that normally suppresses neurite extension) correlates with increased neurite outgrowth.  
  (Source: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf, section 5.5)

3. Blebbistatin  
 • Why MCC: Blebbistatin inhibits myosin II activity, which is involved in actomyosin contraction. Inhibition of this pathway favors neurite extension.  
 • Expected Data: An enhancement of neurite outgrowth (increased neurite area) with no significant reduction in cell viability.  
 • Pathway Effect: Inhibition of myosin II leads to reduced cytoskeletal tension, facilitating neurite outgrowth, which correlates with a positive test response.  
  (Source: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf, section 5.5)

Additional candidates that have been explored in early experiments include microtubule‐disrupting agents such as colchicine, vincristine, and nocodazole. These compounds also inhibit neurite outgrowth by interfering with microtubule dynamics. However, for routine day-to-day performance monitoring, the above three compounds—narciclasine (decreasing neurite area) and HA‑1077/blebbistatin (increasing neurite area)—are preferred because their effects on the underlying Rho/ROCK/myosin II pathway provide consistent and robust changes in the neurite outgrowth endpoint.

Overall, there is a clear correlation between pathway modulation and test method response: activation of the Rho pathway (by narciclasine) leads to reduced neurite growth, whereas inhibition of its downstream effectors (via HA‑1077 or blebbistatin) promotes neurite extension.  
  (Sources: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf, sections 5.5 and 8.3)

Negative controls in this assay are primarily based on the solvent control using 0.1% DMSO. In addition, unspecific controls are employed, which include compounds such as mannitol, paracetamol, ASS, and galloflavin.

These figures reflect the natural variability (“background noise”) of the test system under negative control conditions.

The rationale behind setting the negative control concentration (0.1% DMSO) is to use the minimal solvent concentration required to dissolve test compounds while ensuring that the solvent itself does not influence the assay endpoints. 1. Compound stocks are prepared from solid (powder) material by dissolving them in 100% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). The preferred solvent is DMSO, which is stored in a light‐proof, air‑tight bottle at room temperature. Once dissolved, the solutions are aliquoted in volumes sufficient for one complete experiment (i.e. one biological replicate) in order to avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles that could compromise compound stability and activity.

2. For use in an experiment, one aliquot is thawed and subsequently diluted in a deepwell plate. The diluent is Advanced DMEM/F12 (without supplements) or, in the case of the galactose medium used from day 2 onward, that medium is used (see Section 3.6 for media details). 3. The serial dilution of the compound is typically prepared in the deepwell plate—using a serial dilution factor (default is 1:3, although narrower dilution steps such as 1:1.5 can be applied if needed). In the highest concentration, the dilution is done 1:100 with medium free of DMSO because the initial aliquot already brings in the solvent up to 1% in the diluted series.

4. No explicit mention is made of filtering the stock or dilution solutions for sterility. (If sterility is needed, this is not described in the provided context.)

5. For the final addition, once LUHMES cells are replated into 96‑well plates in 90 µl of galactose-based differentiation medium (without tetracycline, db‑cAMP, and GDNF) on day 2, the compounds are added 30 minutes to 2 hours later – after the cells have attached. A multichannel‐multistepper pipette (using 6 filter tips at a time) is used to dispense 10 µl of each compound dilution into the wells. This achieves a final volume of 100 µl per well.

6. The compound addition is therefore performed in the inner wells of the 96‑well plate (edge wells are filled with PBS/MilliQ water to avoid edge effects) and always after the cells have been re‑plated and allowed a brief attachment period. The procedure does not indicate that compound addition is done in a separate compartment but rather directly into the cell suspension in each well.

Temperature or lighting conditions during compound preparation are not further detailed except that DMSO storage is light-protected and that compounds are thawed immediately prior to dilution.

This overview summarizes the volumes, lab ware (deepwell plates and 96‑well plates), instruments (multichannel‑multistepper pipette with filter tips), choice and role of DMSO as solvent, and how the serial dilutions are prepared and finally added to the test system (Sources: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf – Sections 6.1 and 6.4).

llm_answer:
Several issues have been identified with the assay when testing compounds and during experiment execution. For example, the following problems have been noted:

1. Problematic compounds:
 – Some substances have low solubility in the stock solutions or during dilution, which can lead to precipitation or phase separation when further diluted.  
 – Compounds that are inherently autofluorescent may interfere with the detection of the fluorescence endpoints (calcein-AM for viability and Hoechst H-33342 for nuclei) by adding background signal or obscuring the actual fluorescence (Section 6.5).

2. Hard-to-control experimental variables:
 – Autofluorescence from test compounds or solvent impurities can compromise the readout by interfering with the optimal exposure settings for the microscope.  
 – Variability in compound solubility across batches and during serial dilution poses difficulties in ensuring consistent compound availability in solution (Section 6.5).

3. Critical handling steps and potential pitfalls:
 – Careful pipetting is essential. Pipetting errors can occur if compound droplets are added too high above the medium surface, causing them to stick to the well walls rather than mixing properly.  
 – Adequate training on the use of multichannel/multistepper pipettes is required since errors such as wrong dispense speed or failure to mix properly can lead to variable compound concentrations.  
 – The coating of plates (with PLO/fibronectin) is critical—issues with water quality or differences between PLO/fibronectin lots can lead to cell clumping or uneven distribution. Plates should not be stored in the fridge and must be used immediately after overnight coating (Section 6.5).  
 – Coating quality and the consistency of cell seeding (e.g. proper cell density, appropriate confluency) are critical so that cells are in the right state (round and undifferentiated on treatment) when compounds are added.  
 – Imaging itself is a critical step; for example, focusing failures or imaging only one channel can produce outlier data. Operators must be well trained to ensure both channels (Hoechst and calcein) are imaged correctly (Section 6.5).

4. Robustness issues:
 – Operator training is crucial—operators require about 2–4 weeks of training before they can perform the assay smoothly, and even minor differences in technique (e.g. pipetting speed, timing of compound addition right after cell attachment) can alter outcomes.  
 – Variability may also derive from differences in consumables (e.g., plastic ware from different lots), differences in medium or supplement lots, or even environmental factors (such as seasonal temperature variations affecting cell handling and reagent performance).  
 – Edge effects in 96-well plates are managed by using only the inner 60 wells, as edge wells can experience evaporation or temperature gradients that contribute to variability (Section 6.5).

In summary, the assay is sensitive to issues with compound solubility and autofluorescence, and requires strict control over pipetting, wash/coating procedures, and timing. These factors, alongside operator expertise and differences in consumable quality, represent the main sources of variability and known pitfalls in the method.  

(Sources: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf, Sections 6.1, 6.5)

Raw image data are first processed by the Array Scan VTI HCS Reader software. In summary, the processing steps are as follows (Sources: MitoMetassay(UKN4b).pdf, sections 7.3 and 7.4):

1. Raw images in two channels (Hoechst for nuclei and calcein-AM for viable cell structures, including neurites) are acquired. The software applies flat field and background correction to each image. A dynamically determined intensity threshold (set at 12% of the maximal brightness) is used per field after these corrections.

2. The image analysis algorithms then identify nuclei (in the Hoechst channel) and define a “virtual cell soma area” (VCSA) by expanding the nuclear outlines. The calcein signal in the field is used to define the entire viable cellular structure (VCS). The neurite area is then calculated by subtracting the VCSA (cell body area) from the overall VCS, ensuring that only pixels beyond the cell soma are counted as neurites.

3. In parallel, an algorithm counts only the nuclei that co-localize with a calcein-positive signal (with defined intensity thresholds) to obtain viable cell numbers.

4. The quantified parameters (neurite area and cell counts) are then copied from the Array Scan software into an Excel spreadsheet. At this stage, measured values from medium controls and solvent (e.g. 0.1% DMSO) treated wells serve as the background and untreated control references.

5. Data normalization is performed by converting treated sample values into a percentage of the untreated control (which is set to 100%). This ensures that concentration‐response data are comparable across experiments.

6. Next, concentration–response curves are generated using GraphPad Prism. A nonlinear regression (typically a 4-parameter logistic fit) is applied to the normalized data to derive summary parameters such as EC50 or benchmark concentrations (BMC values). If non‐linear fitting is not feasible, a linear fit is used.

7. In addition, further analyses (e.g. calculation of BMC25 values and subsequent ratios such as BMC25 Viability/BMC25 Neurite Area for hazard evaluation) are performed. The calculated BMC values and their upper and lower confidence intervals (BMCU and BMCL) are determined using the online tool BMCeasy.

Thus, the complete processing workflow starts with background correction and flat field normalization during image analysis, followed by normalization of treated values relative to untreated (solvent control) values and, finally, curve fitting to extract potency and endpoint parameters (e.g. EC50, BMC values, ratios, and PoD).

Below is a summary of the prediction model and the benchmark‐response statistics as outlined in the document:

(i) For dichotomized data, the assay uses two endpoints—neurite area and cell viability. In screening mode, a compound is considered “toxic” if it decreases the neurite area below a defined threshold while viability stays high. In the prediction model, a hit is defined by the following criteria:  
• Neurite area ≤80% of the solvent (DMSO) control  
• Viability ≥90% of the solvent control  
In other words, if neurite outgrowth is reduced by 20% or more without a major drop in viability (≥90%), the compound is classified as toxic (specific for neurite impairment) _(Sources: Sections 5.2, 8.2)_.

(ii) In the case of pseudo-dichotomized outcomes—where there is an intermediate or “borderline” class—the model uses benchmark concentration (BMC) values. Specifically, the ratio of BMC25 for viability (V) over BMC25 for neurite area (NA) is calculated. A ratio ≥4 is considered indicative of a specific neurotoxic effect. However, when the viability endpoint does not reach the BMC25 for calculation, the highest tested concentration (HTC) is used. Thus, compounds with a BMC25 V / BMC25 NA ratio close to 4 form the borderline class between clear non-toxicity and clear neurotoxicity _(Sources: Sections 8.2 and 8.3)_.

(iii) For multi‑class or continuous outcomes, the assay quantifies effects using full concentration–response curves. The responses (neurite area and viability) are fitted (usually by a four‑parameter log function using nonlinear regression) to obtain benchmark concentrations for a 25% change (BMC25). The rationale is twofold:  
 – Biologically, a 25% change is more frequently observed than a 50% change in these endpoints under the assay conditions, and it reflects a sensitive and reproducible response.  
 – Mathematically, the thresholds are set in a context of the intra-experimental variation (for example, the baseline variation has been measured at approximately 11.7 ± 4.5% for neurite outgrowth and 3.8 ± 3.5% for viability).  
Thus, the continuous outcome is interpreted via the ratio of the BMC25 for viability versus neurite area. A ratio ≥4 suggests a specific neurotoxic effect, beyond what would be expected from a general cytotoxic response _(Sources: Sections 8.2, 8.3, and 8.4)_.

Rationale and toxicological basis for the thresholds:  
• The thresholds are benchmarked against the response of narciclasine (used as a positive control), which reliably reduces neurite area (typically falling to around 40–75% of control) with little or no effect on viability.  
• Biologically, the cutoff of ≤80% for neurite area is chosen to capture even moderate impairments in neurite outgrowth, while a viability threshold of ≥90% ensures that the effect is not due to outright cytotoxicity.  
• Mathematically, the variation measures (e.g. ~12% intra-experimental variation for neurite area) support setting a benchmark response that is outside the expected variability.

Limitations of the prediction model include:  
• The model is based on a limited test concentration range and does not always allow a full 50% effect to be observed—hence the use of a 25% benchmark.  
• Handling variations (e.g. differences in cell passage, plastic coating, and pipetting precision) can affect the baseline response and may limit reproducibility.  
• The model is tuned to detect effects on neurite outgrowth in human dopaminergic neurons and might not capture toxic mechanisms that do not predominantly affect this endpoint.  
• In some cases the viability may not drop sufficiently to allow calculation of a BMC25, requiring the use of the highest tested concentration instead.

When the assay is used in screening mode, a “hit” is defined as a compound that meets the toxicity criteria for the dichotomized data—that is, it causes neurite area reduction to ≤80% of the control while keeping viability at ≥90%—which indicates a specific impairment of neurite outgrowth rather than generalized cytotoxicity _(Sources: Sections 5.2, 8.2, and 8.3)_.
